sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Pollux, I have a commission for you; next time you go up—and I think it is your turn for earth to-morrow—if you come across Menippus the Cynic—you will find him about the Craneum at Corinth, or in the Lyceum, laughing at the philosophers’ disputes—well, give him this message:—Menippus, Diogenes advises you, if mortal subjects for laughter begin to pall, to come down below, and find much richer material; where you are now, there is always a dash of uncertainty in it; the question will always intrude—who can be quite sure about the hereafter? Here, you can have your laugh out in security, like me; it is the best of sport to see millionaires, governors, despots, now mean and insignificant; you can only tell them by their lamentations, and the spiritless despondency which is the legacy of better days. Tell him this, and mention that he had better stuff his wallet with plenty of lupines, and any unconsidered trifles he can snap up in the way of pauper doles In the Greek, 'a Hecate’s repast lying at a street corner.' 'Rich men used to make offerings to Hecate on the 30th of every month as Goddess of roads at street corners; and these offerings were at once pounced upon by the poor, or, as here, the Cynics.' Jacobitz. or lustral eggs'Eggs were often used as purificatory offerings and set out in front of the house purified.’ Jacobitz..

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: I will tell him, Diogenes. But give me some idea of his appearance.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
Old, bald, with a cloak that allows him plenty of light
and ventilation, and is patched all colours of the rainbow; always laughing, and usually gibing at pretentious philosophers,

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: Ah, I cannot mistake him now.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: May I give you another message to those same philosophers?

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: Oh, I don’t mind; go on.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Charge them generally to give up playing the fool, quarrelling over metaphysics, tricking each other with horn and crocodile puzzles,See Puzzles in Notes. and teaching people to waste wit on such absurdities.

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: Oh, but if I say anything against their wisdom, they will call me an ignorant blockhead.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Then tell them from me to go to the devil.

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: Very well; rely upon me.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: And then, my most obliging of Polluxes, there is this for the rich:—O vain fools, why hoard gold? why all these pains over interest sums and the adding of hundred to hundred, when you must shortly come to us with nothing beyond the dead-penny?

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: They shall have their message too.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Ah, and a word to the handsome and strong; Megillus of Corinth, and Damoxenus the wrestler will do. Inform them that auburn locks, eyes bright or black, rosy cheeks, are as little in fashion here as tense muscles or mighty shoulders; man and man are as like as two peas, tell them, when it comes to bare skull and no beauty.

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: That is to the handsome and strong; yes, I can manage that.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
Yes, my Spartan, and here is for the poor. There are a great many of them, very sorry for themselves and resentful of their helplessness. Tell them to dry their tears and cease their cries; explain to them that here one man is as good as
another, and they will find those who were rich on earth no better than themselves. As for your Spartans, -you will not mind scolding them, from me, upon their present degeneracy?

sp.speaker: Pollux
sp.p: No, no, Diogenes; leave Sparta alone; that is going too far; your other commissions I will execute.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Oh, well, let them off, if you care about it; but tell all the others what I said.

div.head: Before Pluto: Croesus, Midas, and Sardanapalus against Menippus

sp.speaker: Croesus
sp.p: Pluto, we can stand this snarling Cynic no longer in our neighbourhood; either you must transfer him to other quarters, or we are going to migrate,

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Why, what harm does he do to your ghostly community?

sp.speaker: Croesus
sp.p: Midas here, and Sardanapalus and I, can never get in a good cry over the old days of gold and luxury and treasure, but he must be laughing at us, and calling us rude names; ‘slaves’ and ‘garbage,’ he says we are. And then he sings; and that throws us out.—In short, he is a nuisance,

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Menippus, what’s this I hear?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: All perfectly true, Pluto. I detest these abject rascals! Not content with having lived the abominable lives they did, they keep on talking about it now they are dead, and harping on the good old days. I take a positive pleasure in annoying them,

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Yes, but you mustn’t. They have had terrible losses; they feel it deeply.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Pluto! you are not going to lend your countenance to these whimpering fools?

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: It isn’t that; but I won’t have you quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p:
Well, you scum of your respective nations, let there be no misunderstanding: I am going on just the same. Wherever
you are, there shall I be also; worrying, jeering, singing you down.

sp.speaker: Croesus
sp.p: Presumption!

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Not a bit of it. Yours was the presumption, when you expected men to fall down before you, when you trampled on men’s liberty, and forgot there was such a thing as death. Now comes the weeping and gnashing of teeth: for all is lost!

sp.speaker: Croesus
sp.p: Lost! Ah God! My treasure-heapp——

sp.speaker: Midas
sp.p: My gold——

sp.speaker: Sardanapalus
sp.p: My little comforts——

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: That’s right: stick to it! You do the whining, and I'll chime in with a string of cnotHi-saurons, best of accompaniments,

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Now I wonder how it is that you two dead men have been honoured with temples and taken for prophets; those silly mortals imagine you are Gods.

sp.speaker: Ampbilochus
sp.p: How can we help it, if they are fools enough to have such fancies about the dead?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Ah, they would never have had them, though, if you had not been charlatans in your lifetime, and pretended to know the future and be able to foretell it to your clients.

sp.speaker: Trophonius
sp.p: Well, Menippus, Amphilochus can take his own line, if he likes; as for me, I am a Hero, and do give oracles to any one who comes down to me. It is pretty clear you were never at Lebadea, or you would not be so incredulous.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p:
What do you mean? I must go to Lebadea, swaddle myself up in absurd linen, take a cake in my hand, and crawl through a narrow passage into a cave, before I could tell that you are a dead man, with nothing but knavery to differentiate
you from the rest of us? Now, on your seer-ship, what is a Hero? I am sure I don’t know.

sp.speaker: Trophonius
sp.p: He is half God, and half man,

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: So what is neither man (as you imply) nor God, is both at once? Well, at present what has become of your diviner half?

sp.speaker: Trophonius
sp.p: He gives oracles in Boeotia.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: What you may mean is quite beyond me; the one thing I know for certain is that you are dead—the whole of you.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Ferryman, what do you say to settling up accounts? It will prevent any unpleasantness later on.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Very good. It does save trouble to get these things straight.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: One anchor, to your order, five shillings.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: That is a lot of money.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: So help me Pluto, it is what I had to pay. One rowlock-strap, fourpence,

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Five and four; put that down.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Then there was a needle, for mending the sail; tenpence.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Down with it.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Caulking-wax; nails; and cord for the brace. Two shillings the lot.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: They were worth the money.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: That’s all; unless I have forgotten anything. When will you pay it?

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: I can’t just now, Hermes; we shall have a war or a plague presently, and then the passengers will come shoaling in, and I shall be able to make a little by jobbing the fares.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: So for the present I have nothing to do but sit down, and pray for the worst, as my only chance of getting paid?

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: There is nothing else for it;—very little business doing just now, as you see, owing to the peace.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: That is just as well, though it does keep me waiting for my money. After all, though, Charon, in old days men were men; you remember the state they used to come down in,—all blood and wounds generally. Nowadays, a man is poisoned by his slave or his wife; or gets dropsy from overfeeding; a pale, spiritless lot, nothing like-the men of old. Most of them seem to meet their end in some plot that has money for its object.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Ah; money is in great request.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Yes; you can’t blame me if I am somewhat urgent for payment.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: You know that old, old fellow, Eucrates the millionaire— no children, but a few thousand would-be heirs?

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Yes—lives at Sicyon. Well?

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Well, Hermes, he is ninety now; let him live as much longer, please; I should like it to be more still, if possible; and bring me down his toadies one by one, that young Charinus, Damon, and the rest of them.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: It would seem so strange, wouldn’t it?

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p:
On the contrary, it would be ideal justice. What business have they to pray for his death, or pretend to his money? they are no relations. The most abominable thing about it is that they vary these prayers with every public attention; when he is ill, every one knows what they are after, and yet they vow offerings if he recovers; talk of versatility! So let
him be immortal, and bring them away before him with their mouths still open for the fruit that never drops.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Well, they are rascals, and it would be a comic ending. He leads them a pretty life too, on hope gruel; he always looks more dead than alive, but he is tougher than a young man. They have divided up the inheritance among them, and feed on imaginary bliss.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Just so; now he is to throw off his years like Iolaus, and rejuvenate, while they in the middle of their hopes find themselves here with their dream-wealth left behind them. Nothing like making the punishment fit the crime.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Say no more, Pluto; I will fetch you them one after another; seven of them, is it?

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Down with them; and he shall change from an old man to a blooming youth, and attend their funerals.

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p: Now is this fair, Pluto,—that I should die at the age of thirty, and that old Thucritus go on living past ninety?

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Nothing could be fairer. Thucritus lives and is in no hurry for his neighbours to die; whereas you always had some design against him; you were waiting to step into his shoes.

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p: Well, an old man like that is past getting any enjoyment out of his money; he ought to die, and make room for younger men.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: This is a novel principle: the man who can no longer derive pleasure from his money is to die!—Fate and Nature have ordered it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p:
Then they have ordered it wrongly. There ought to be a proper sequence according to seniority. Things are turned upside down, if an old man is to go on living with only three
teeth in his head, half blind, tottering about with a pair of slaves on each side to hold him up, drivelling and rheumy-eyed, having no joy of life, a living tomb, the derision of his juniors,— and young men are to die in the prime of their strength and beauty. ’Tis contrary to nature. At any rate the young men have a right to know when the old are going to die, so that they may not throw away their attentions on them for nothing, as is sometimes the case. The present arrangement is a putting of the cart before the horse.:

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: There is a great deal more sound sense in it than you suppose, Terpsion. Besides, what right have you young fellows got to be prying after other men’s goods, and thrusting yourselves upon your childless elders? You look rather foolish, when you get buried first; it tickles people immensely; the more fervent your prayers for the death of your aged friend, the greater is the general exultation when you precede him. It has become quite a profession lately, this amorous devotion to old men and women,—childless, of course; children destroy the illusion. By the way though, some of the beloved objects see through your dirty motives well enough by now; they have children, but they pretend to hate them, and so have lovers all the same. When their wills come to be read, their faithful bodyguard is not included: nature asserts itself, the children get their rights, and the lovers realize, with gnashings of teeth, that they have been taken in.

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p:
Too true! The luxuries that Thucritus has enjoyed at my expense! He always looked as if he were at the point of death. I never went to see him, but he would groan and squeak like a chicken barely out of the shell: I considered that he might step into his coffin at any moment, and heaped gift upon gift, for fear of being outdone in generosity by my rivals; I passed anxious, sleepless nights, reckoning and arranging all; ’twas this, the sleeplessness and the anxiety, that brought me
to my death. And he swallows my bait whole, and attends my funeral chuckling.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Well done, Thucritus! Long may you live to enjoy your wealth,—and your joke at the youngsters’ expense; many a toady may you send hither before your own time comes!

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p: Now I think of it, it would be a satisfaction if Charoeades were to die before him.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Charoeades! My dear Terpsion, Phido, Melanthus,— every one of them will be here before Thucritus,—all victims of this same anxiety!

sp.speaker: Terpsion
sp.p: That is as it should be. Hold on, Thucritus!

sp.speaker: Zenophantus
sp.p: Ah, Callidemides, and how did you come by your end? As for me, I was free of Dinias’s table, and there died of a surfeit; but that is stale news; you were there, of course.

sp.speaker: Callidemides
sp.p: Yes, I was. Now there was an element of surprise about my fate. I suppose you know that old Ptoeodorus?

sp.speaker: Zenophantus
sp.p: The rich man with no children, to whom you gave most of your company?

sp.speaker: Callidemides
sp.p: That is the man; he had promised to leave me his heir, and I used to show my appreciation. However, it went on such a time; Tithonus was a juvenile to him; so I found a short cut to my property. I bought a potion, and agreed with the butler that next time his master called for wine (he is a pretty stiff drinker) he should have this ready in a cup and present it; and I was pledged to reward the man with his freedom.

sp.speaker: Zenophantus
sp.p: And what happened? this is interesting.

sp.speaker: Callidemides
sp.p:
When we came from bath, the young fellow had two cups ready, one with the poison for Ptoeodorus, and the other for me; but by some blunder he handed me the poisoned cup,
and Ptoeodorus the plain; and behold, before he had done drinking, there was I sprawling on the ground, a vicarious corpse! Why are you laughing so, Zenophantus? I am your friend; such mirth is unseemly.

sp.speaker: Zenophantus
sp.p: Well, it was such a humorous exit. And how did the old man behave?

sp.speaker: Callidemides
sp.p: He was dreadfully distressed for the moment; then he saw, I suppose, and laughed as much as you over the butler’s trick,

sp.speaker: Zenophantus
sp.p: Ah, short cuts are no better for you than for other people, you see; the high road would have been safer, if not quite so quick.

sp.speaker: Cnemon
sp.p: Why, ’tis the proverb fulfilled! The fawn hath taken the lion.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: What’s the matter, Cnemon?

sp.speaker: Cnemon
sp.p: The matter! I have been fooled, miserably fooled. I have passed over all whom I should have liked to make my heirs, and left my money to the wrong man.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: How was that?

sp.speaker: Cnemon
sp.p: I had been speculating on the death of Hermolaus, the millionaire. He had no children, and my attentions had been well received by him. I thought it would be a good idea to let him know that I had made my will in his favour, on the chance of its exciting his emulation.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: Yes; and Hermolaus?

sp.speaker: Cnemon
sp.p: What his will was, I don’t know. I died suddenly,— the roof came down about my ears; and now Hermolaus is my heir The pike has swallowed hook and bait.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: And your anglership into the bargain. The pit that you digged for other....

sp.speaker: Cnemon
sp.p: That’s about the truth of the matter, confound it.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: So here you are at last, Polystratus; you must be something very like a centenarian.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Ninety-eight.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: And what sort of a life have you had of it, these thirty years? you were about seventy when I died.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Delightful, though you may find it hard to believe.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: It ¢s surprising that you could have any joy of your life— old, weak, and childless, moreover.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: In the first place, I could do just what I liked; there were still plenty of handsome boys and dainty women; perfumes were sweet, wine kept its bouquet, Sicilian feasts were nothing to mine,

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: This is a change, to be sure; you were very economical in my day.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Ah, but, my simple friend, these good things were presents—came in streams. From dawn my doors were thronged with visitors, and in the day it was a procession of the fairest gifts of earth.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Why, you must have seized the crown after my death.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Oh no, it was only that I inspired a number of tender passions,

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Tender passions, indeed! what, you, an old man with hardly a tooth left in your head!

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p:
Certainly; the first of our townsmen were in love with me. Such as you see me, old, bald, blear-eyed, rheumy, they
delighted to do me honour; happy was the man on whom my glance rested a moment.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Well, then, you had some adventure like Phaon’s, when he rowed Aphrodite across from Chios; your God granted your prayer and made you young and fair and lovely again.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: No, no; I was as you see me, and I was the object of all desire.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Oh, I give it up.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Why, I should have thought you knew the violent passion for old men who have plenty of money and no children.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Ah, now I comprehend your beauty, old fellow; it was the Golden Aphrodite bestowed it.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: I assure you, Simylus, I had a good deal of satisfaction out of my lovers; they idolized me, almost. Often I would be coy and shut some of them out. Such rivalries! such jealous emulations!

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: And how did you dispose of your fortune in the end?

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: I gave each an express promise to make him my heir; he believed, and treated me to more attentions than ever; meanwhile I had another genuine will, which was the one I left, with a message to them all to go hang.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Who was the heir by this one? one of your relations, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: Not likely; it was a handsome young Phrygian I had lately bought.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Age?

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p: About twenty.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Ah, I can guess his office.

sp.speaker: Polystratus
sp.p:
Well, you know, he deserved the inheritance much better than they did; he was a barbarian and a rascal; but by this time he has the best of society at his beck. So he inherited; and now he is one of the aristocracy; his smooth chin and his
foreign accent are no bars to his being called nobler than Codrus, handsomer than Nireus, wiser than Odysseus.

sp.speaker: Simylus
sp.p: Well, I don’t mind; let him be Emperor of Greece, if he likes, so long as he keeps the property away from that other crew.

div.head: Charon. Hermes. Menippus and other Shades

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: I'll tell you how things stand. Our craft, as you see, is small, and leaky, and three-parts rotten; a single lurch, and she will capsize without more ado. And here are all you passengers, each with his luggage. If you come on board like that, I am afraid you may have cause to repent it; especially those who have not learnt to swim.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Then how are we to make a trip of it?

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: I'll tell you. They must leave all this nonsense behind them on shore, and come aboard in their skins. As it is, there will be no room to spare. And in future, Hermes, mind you admit no one till he has cleared himself of encumbrances, as I say. Stand by the gangway, and keep an eye on them, and make them strip before you let them pass.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Very good. Well, Number One, who are you?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Menippus. Here are my wallet and staff; overboard with them. I had the sense not to bring my cloak.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Pass on, Menippus; you’re a good fellow; you shall have the seat of honour, up by the pilot, where you can see every one.—

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Here is a handsome person; who is he?

sp.speaker: Charmoleos
sp.p: Charmoleos of Megara; the irresistible, whose kiss was worth a thousand pounds,

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: That beauty must come off,—lips, kisses, and all; the flowing locks, the blushing cheeks, the skin entire. That’s right. Now we're in better trim;—you may pass on.—

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: And who is the stunning gentleman in the purple and the diadem?

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: I am Lampichus, tyrant of Gela.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: And what is all this splendour doing here, Lampichus?

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: How! would you have a tyrant come hither stripped?

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: A tyrant! That would be too much to expect. But with a shade we must insist. Off with these things.

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: There, then:-away goes my wealth.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Pomp must go too, and pride; we shall be overfreighted else.

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: At least let me keep my diadem and robes.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: No, no; off they come!

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: Well? That is all, as you see for yourself.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: There is something more yet: cruelty, folly, insolence, hatred.

sp.speaker: Lampichus
sp.p: There then: I am bare.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Pass on.—And who may you be, my bulky friend?

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: Damasias the athlete.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: To be sure; many is the time I have seen you in the gymnasium.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: You have. Well, I have peeled; let me pass.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Peeled! my dear sir, what, with all this fleshy encumbrance? Come, off with it; we should go to the bottom if you put one foot aboard. And those crowns, those victories, remove them.

sp.speaker: Damasias
sp.p: There; no mistake about it this time; I am as light as any shade among them.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: That’s more the kind of thing. On with you.—Crato, you can take off that wealth and luxury and effeminacy; and we can’t have that funeral pomp here, nor those ancestral glories either; down with your rank and reputation, and any votes of thanks or inscriptions you have about you; and you need not tell us what size your tomb was; remarks of that kind come heavy.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Well, if I must, I must; there’s no help for it.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Hullo! in full armour? What does this mean? and why this trophy?

sp.speaker: A General
sp.p: I am a great conqueror; a valiant warrior; my country’s pride.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: The trophy may stop behind; we are at peace; there is no demand for arms.—

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Whom have we here? whose is this knitted brow, this flowing beard? 'Tis some reverend sage, if outside goes for anything; he mutters; he is wrapped in meditation.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: That’s a philosopher, Hermes; and an impudent quack into the bargain. Have him out of that cloak; you will find something to amuse you underneath it.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Off with your clothes first; and then we will see to the rest. My goodness, what a bundle: quackery, ignorance, quarrelsomeness, vainglory; idle questionings, prickly arguments, intricate conceptions; humbug and gammon and wishywashy hair-splittings without end; and hullo! why here’s avarice, and self-indulgence, and impudence! luxury, effeminacy and peevishness!—Yes, I see them all; you need not try to hide them. Away with falsehood and swagger and superciliousness; why, the three-decker is not built that would hold you with all this luggage.

sp.speaker: A Philosopher
sp.p: I resign them all, since such is your bidding.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Have his beard off too, Hermes; only look what a ponderous bush of a thing! There’s a good five pounds’ weight there.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Yes; the beard must go.

sp.speaker: A Philosopher
sp.p: And who shall shave me?

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Menippus here shall take it off with the carpenter’s axe; the gangway will serve for a block.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Oh, can’t I have a saw, Hermes? It would be much better fun.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: The axe must serve.—Shrewdly chopped!—Why, you look more like a man and less like a goat already.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: A little off the eyebrows?

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Why, certainly; he has trained them up all over his forehead, for reasons best known to himself—Worm! what, snivelling? afraid of death? Oh, get on board with you.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: He has still got the biggest thumper of all under his arm.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: What’s that?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Flattery; many is the good turn that has done him.

sp.speaker: A Philosopher
sp.p: Oh, all right, Menippus; suppose you leave your independence behind you, and your plain-speaking, and your indifference, and your high spirit, and your jests!—No one else here has a jest about him.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Don’t you, Menippus! you stick to them; useful commodities, these, on shipboard; light and handy.—

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: You rhetorician there, with your verbosities and your barbarisms, your antitheses and balances and periods, off with the whole pack of them.

sp.speaker: A Rhetorician
sp.p: Away they go.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: All’s ready. Loose the cable, and pull in the gangway; haul up the anchor; spread all sail; and, pilot, look to your helm. Good luck to our voyage!—

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: What are you all whining about, you fools? You philosopher, late of the beard,—you’re as bad as any of them.

sp.speaker: A Philosopher
sp.p: Ah, Hermes: I had thought that the soul was immortal.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: He lies: that is not the cause of his distress.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: What is it, then?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: He knows that he will never have a good dinner again; never sneak about at night with his cloak over his head, going the round of the brothels; never spend his mornings in fooling boys out of their money, under the pretext of teaching them wisdom.

sp.speaker: A Philosopher
sp.p: And pray are you content to be dead?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p:
It may be presumed so, as I sought death of my own
accord.—

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: By the way, I surely heard a noise, as if people were shouting on the earth?

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: You did; and from more than one quarter.—There are people running in a body to the Town-hall, exulting over the death of Lampichus; the women have got hold of his wife; his infant children fare no better,—the boys are giving them a handsome pelting. Then again you hear the applause that greets the orator Diophantus, as he pronounces the funeral oration of our friend Crato. Ah yes, and that’s Damasias’s mother, with her women, striking up a dirge. No one has a tear for you, Menippus; your remains are left in peace. Privileged person!

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Wait a bit: before long you will hear the mournful howl of dogs, and the beating of crows’ wings, as they gather to perform my funeral rites.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: I like your spirit——However, here we are in port. Away with you all to the judgement-seat; it is straight ahead. The ferryman and I must go back for a fresh load.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Good voyage to you, Hermes.—Let us be getting on; what are you all waiting for? We have got to face the judge, sooner or later; and by all accounts his sentences are no joke; wheels, rocks, vultures are mentioned. Every detail of our lives will now come to light!

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Did you know Moerichus of Corinth, Diogenes? A shipowner, rolling in money, with a cousin called Aristeas, nearly as rich. He had a Homeric quotation Wilt thou heave me? shall I heave thee?Homer, Il. xxiii. 724. When Ajax and Odysseus have wrestled for some time without either’s producing any impression, and the spectators are getting tired of it, the former proposes a change in tactics, '"Let us hoist—try you with me or I with you." The idea evidently is that each in turn is to offer only a passive resistance, and let his adversary try to fling him thus.’ Leaf.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: What was the point of it?

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Why, the cousins were of equal age, expected to succeed to each other’s wealth, and behaved accordingly. They published their wills, each naming the other sole heir in case of his own prior decease. So it stood in black and white, and they vied with each other in showing that deference which the relation demands. Ali the prophets, astrologers, and Chaldean dream-interpreters alike, and Apollo himself for that matter, held different views at different times about the winner; the thousands seemed to incline now to Aristeas’s side, now to Moerichus’s.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: And how did it end? I am quite curious.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: They both died on the same day, and the properties passed to Eunomius and Thrasycles, two relations who had never had a presentiment of it. They had been crossing from Sicyon to Cirrha, when they were taken aback by a squall from the north-west, and capsized in mid-channel.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Cleverly done. Now, when we were alive, we never had such designs on one another. I never prayed for Antisthenes’s death, with a view to inheriting his staff—though it was an extremely serviceable one, which he had cut himself from a wild olive; and I do not credit you, Crates, with ever having had an eye to my succession; it included the tub, and a wallet with two pints of lupines in it.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Why, no; these things were superfluities to me—and to yourself, indeed. The real necessities you inherited from Antisthenes, and I from you; and in those necessities was more grandeur and majesty than in the Persian Empire.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: You allude to—.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Wisdom, independence, truth, frankness, freedom.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: To be sure; now I think of it, I did inherit all this from Antisthenes, and left it to you with some addition.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Others, however, were not interested in such property; no one paid us the attentions of an expectant heir; they all had their eyes on gold, instead.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Of course; they had no receptacle for such things as we could give; luxury had made them so leaky—as full of holes as a worn-out purse. Put wisdom, frankness, or truth into them, and it would have dropped out; the bottom of the bag would have let them through, like the perforated cask into which those poor Danaids are always pouring. Gold, on the other hand, they could grip with tooth or nail or somehow.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Result: our wealth will still be ours down here; while they will arrive with no more than one penny, and even that must be left with the ferryman.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Libyan, I claim precedence of you. I am the better man.

sp.speaker: Hannibal
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Then let Minos decide.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Who are you both?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: This is Hannibal, the Carthaginian: I am Alexander, the son of Philip.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Bless me, a distinguished pair! And what is the quarrel about?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: It is a question of precedence. He says he is the better general: and I maintain that neither Hannibal nor (I might almost add) any of my predecessors was my equal in strategy; all the world knows that.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Well, you shall each have your say in turn: the Libyan first.

sp.speaker: Hannibal
sp.p: Fortunately for me, Minos, I have mastered Greek since I have been here; so that my adversary will not have even that advantage of me. Now I hold that the highest praise is due to those who have won their way to greatness from obscurity; who have clothed themselves in power, and shown themselves fit for dominion. I myself entered Spain with a handful of men, took service under my brother, and was found worthy of the supreme command. I conquered the Celtiberians, subdued Western Gaul, crossed the Alps, overran the valley of the Po, sacked town after town, made myself master of the plains, approached the bulwarks of the capital, and in one day slew such a host, that their finger-rings were measured by bushels, and the rivers were bridged by their bodies. And this I did, though I had never been called a son of Ammon; I never pretended to be a god, never related visions of my mother; I made no secret of the fact that I was mere flesh and blood. My rivals were the ablest generals in the world, commanding the best soldiers in the world; I warred not with Medes or Assyrians, who fly before they are pursued, and yield the victory to him that dares take it.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p:
on the other hand, in increasing and extending as he did the dominion which he had inherited from his father, was but following the impetus given to him by Fortune. And this conqueror had no sooner crushed his puny adversary by the victories of Issus and Arbela, than he forsook the traditions of his country, and lived the life of a Persian; accepting the prostrations of his subjects, assassinating his friends at his own table, or handing them over to the executioner. I in my command respected the freedom of my country, delayed not to obey her summons, when the enemy with their huge armament invaded Libya, laid aside the privileges of my office, and
submitted to my sentence withouta murmur. Yet I wasa barbarian all unskilled in Greek culture; I could not recite Homer, nor had I enjoyed the advantages of Aristotle’s instruction; I had to make a shift with such qualities as were mine by nature.— It is on these grounds that I claim the pre-eminence. My rival has indeed all the lustre that attaches to the wearing of a diadem, and—I know not—for Macedonians such things may have charms: but I cannot think that this circumstance constitutes a higher claim than the courage and genius of one who owed nothing to Fortune, and everything to his own resolution.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Not bad, for a Libyan.—Well, Alexander, what do you say to that?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Silence, Minos, would be the best answer to such confident self-assertion. The tongue of Fame will suffice of itself to convince you that I was a great prince, and my opponent a petty adventurer. But I would have you consider the distance between us. Called to the throne while I was yet a boy, I quelled the disorders of my kingdom, and avenged my father’s murder. By the destruction of Thebes, I inspired the Greeks with such awe, that they appointed me their commander-inchief; and from that moment, scorning to confine myself to the kingdom that I inherited from my father, I extended my gaze over the entire face of the earth, and thought it shame if I should govern less than the whole. With a small force I invaded Asia, gained a great victory on the Granicus, took Lydia, Tonia, Phrygia,—in short, subdued all that was within my reach, before I commenced my march for Issus, where Darius was waiting for me at the head of his myriads.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p:
You know the sequel: yourselves can best say what was the number of the dead whom on one day I dispatched hither. The ferryman tells me that his boat would not hold them; most of them had to come across on rafts of their own construction. In these enterprises, I was ever at the head of my troops, ever courted danger. To
say nothing of Tyre and Arbela, I penetrated into India, and carried my empire to the shores of Ocean; I captured elephants; I conquered Porus; I crossed the Tanais, and worsted the Scythians—no mean enemies—in a tremendous cavalry engagement. I heaped benefits upon my friends: I made my enemie’, taste my resentment. If men took me for a god, I cannot blame them; the vastness of my undertakings might excuse such a belief. But to conclude.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: I died a king: Hannibal, a fugitive at the court of the Bithynian Prusias—fitting end for villany and cruelty. Of his Italian victories I say nothing; they were the fruit not of honest legitimate warfare, but of treachery, craft, and dissimulation. He taunts me with selfindulgence: my illustrious friend has surely forgotten the pleasant time he spent in Capua among the ladies, while the precious moments fleeted by. Had I not scorned the Western world, and turned my attention to the East, what would it have cost me to make the bloodless conquest of Italy, and Libya, and all, as far West as Gades? But nations that already cowered beneath a master were unworthy of my sword.—I have finished, Minos, and await your decision; of the many arguments I might have used, these shall suffice,

sp.speaker: Scipio
sp.p: First, Minos, let me speak.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: And who are you, friend? and where do you come from?

sp.speaker: Scipio
sp.p: I am Scipio, the Roman general, who destroyed Carthage, and gained great victories over the Libyans.

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Well, and what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Scipio
sp.p: That Alexander is my superior, and I am Hannibal’s, having defeated him, and driven him to ignominious flight. What impudence is this, to contend with Alexander, to whom I, your conqueror, would not presume to compare myself!

sp.speaker: Minos
sp.p: Honestly spoken, Scipio, on my word! Very well, then: Alexander comes first, and you next; and I think we must say Hannibal third. And a very creditable third, too.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Dear me, Alexander, you dead like the rest of us?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: As you see, sir; is there anything extraordinary in a mortal’s dying?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: So Ammon lied when he said you were his son; you were Philip’s after all.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Apparently; if I had been Ammon’s, I should not have died.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Strange! there were tales of the same order about Olympias too. A serpent visited her, and was seen in her bed; we were given to understand that that was how you came into the world, and Philip made a mistake when he took you for his.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Yes, I was told all that myself; however, I know now that my mother’s and the Ammon stories were all moonshine.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Their lies were of some practical value to you, though; your divinity brought a good many people to their knees.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: But now, whom did you leave your great empire to?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Diogenes, I cannot tell you. I had no time to leave any directions about it, beyond just giving Perdiccas my ring as I died, Why are you laughing?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Oh, I was only thinking of the Greeks’ behaviour; directly you succeeded, how they flattered you! their elected patron, generalissimo against the barbarian; one of the twelve Gods according to some; temples built and sacrifices offered to the Serpent’s son!

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: If I may ask, where did your Macedonians bury you?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: I have lain in Babylon a full month to-day; and Ptolemy of the Guards is pledged, as soon as he can get a moment’s respite from present disturbances, to take and bury me in Egypt, there to be reckoned among the Gods.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I have some reason to laugh, you see; still nursing vain hopes of developing into an Osiris or Anubis! Pray, your Godhead, put these expectations from you; none may reascend who has once sailed the lake and penetrated our entrance; Aeacus is watchful, and Cerberus an awkward customer.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: But there is one thing I wish you would tell me: how do you like thinking over all the earthly bliss you left to come here—your guards and armour-bearers and lieutenant-governors, your heaps of gold and adoring peoples, Babylon and Bactria, your huge elephants, your honour and glory, those conspicuous drives with white-cinctured locks and clasped purple cloak? does the thought of them hurt? What, crying? silly fellow! did not your wise Aristotle include in his instructions any hint of the insecurity of fortune’s favours?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Wise? call him the craftiest of all flatterers. Allow me to know a little more than other people about Aristotle; his requests and his letters came to my address; I know how he profited by my passion for culture; how he would toady and compliment me, to be sure! now it was my beauty—that too is included under The Good; now it was my deeds and my money; for money too he called a Good—he meant that he was not going to be ashamed of taking it. Ah, Diogenes, an impostor; and a past master at it too. For me, the result of his wisdom is that I am distressed for the things you catalogued just now, as if I had lost in them the chief Goods.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Wouldst know thy course? I will prescribe for your distress. Our flora, unfortunately, does not include hellebore; but you take plenty of Lethe-water—good, deep, repeated draughts; that will relieve your distress over the Aristotelian Goods. Quick; here are Clitus, Callisthenes, and a lot of others making for you; they mean to tear you in pieces and pay you out. Here, go the opposite way; and remember, repeated draughts.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: You cannot deny that you are my son this time, Alexander; you would not have died if you had been Ammon’s.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: I knew all the time that you, Philip, son of Amyntas, were my father. I only accepted the statement of the oracle because I thought it was good policy.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: What, to suffer yourself to be fooled by lying priests?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: No, but it had an awe-inspiring effect upon the barbarians. When they thought they had a God to deal with, they gave up the struggle; which made their conquest a simple matter.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: And whom did you ever conquer that was worth conquering? Your adversaries were ever timid creatures, with their bows and their targets and their wicker shields. It was other work conquering the Greeks: Boeotians, Phocians, Athenians; Arcadian hoplites, Thessalian cavalry, javelin-men from Elis, peltasts of Mantinea; Thracians, Illyrians, Paeonians; to subdue these was something. But for gold-laced womanish Medes and Persians and Chaldaeans,—why, it had been done before: did you never hear of the expedition of the Ten Thousand under Clearchus? and how the enemy would not even come to blows with them, but ran away before they were within bow-shot?

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: Still, there were the Scythians, father, and the Indian elephants; they were no joke. And my conquests were not gained by dissension or treachery; I broke no oath, no promise, nor ever purchased victory at the expense of honour. As to the Greeks, most of them joined me without a struggle; and I dare say you have heard how I handled Thebes.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p:
I know all about that; I had it from Clitus, whom you
ran through the body, in the middle of dinner, because he presumed to mention my achievements in the same breath with yours.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: They tell me too that you took to aping the manners of your conquered Medes; abandoned the Macedonian cloak in favour of the candys, assumed the upright tiara, and exacted oriental prostrations from Macedonian freemen! This is delicious. As to your brilliant matches, and your beloved Hephaestion, and your scholars in lions’ cages,—the less said the better. I have only heard one thing to your credit: you respected the person of Darius’s beautiful wife, and you provided for his mother and daughters; there you acted like a king.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: And have you nothing to say of my adventurous spirit, father, when I was the first to leap down within the ramparts of Oxydracae, and was covered with wounds?

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: Not a word. Not that it is a bad thing, in my opinion, for a king to get wounded occasionally, and to face danger at the head of his troops: but this was the last thing that you were called upon to do. You were passing for a God; and your being wounded, and carried off the field on a litter, bleeding and, groaning, could only excite the ridicule of the spectators: Ammon stood convicted of quackery, his oracle of falsehood, his priests of flattery. The son of Zeus in a swoon, requiring medical assistance! who could help laughing at the sight? And now that you have died, can you doubt that many a jest is being cracked on the subject of your divinity, as men contemplate the God’s corpse laid out for burial, and already going the way of all flesh? Besides, your achievements lose half their credit from this very circumstance which you say was so useful in facilitating your conquests: nothing you did could come up to your divine reputation.

sp.speaker: Alexander
sp.p: The world thinks otherwise. I am ranked with Heracles and Dionysus; and, for that matter, I took Aornos, which was more than either of them could do.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: There spoke the son of Ammon, Heracles and Dionysus, indeed! You ought to be ashamed of yourself, Alexander; when will you learn to drop that bombast, and know yourself for the shade that you are?

sp.speaker: Antilochus
sp.p: Achilles, what you were saying to Odysseus the other day about death was very poor-spirited; I should have expected better things from a pupil of Chiron and Phoenix. I was listening; you said you would rather be a servant on earth to some poor hind ‘of scanty livelihood possessed,’ than king of all the dead. Such sentiments might have been very well in the mouth of a poor-spirited cowardly Phrygian, dishonourably in love with life: for the son of Peleus, boldest of all Heroes, so to vilify himself, is a disgrace; it gives the lie to all your life; you might have had a long inglorious reign in Phthia, and your own choice was death and glory.

sp.speaker: Achilles
sp.p: In those days, son of Nestor, I knew not this place; ignorant whether of those two was the better, I esteemed that flicker of fame more than life; now I see that it is worthless, let folk up there make what verses of it they will. 'Tis dead level among the dead, Antilochus; strength and beauty are no more; we welter all in the same gloom, one no better than another; the shades of Trojans fear me not, Achaeans pay me no reverence; each may say what he will; a man is a ghost, ‘or be he churl, or be he peer.’ It irks me; I would fain be a servant, and alive.

sp.speaker: Antilochus
sp.p:
But what help, Achilles? ’tis Nature’s decree that by all means all die. We must abide by her law, and not fret at her commands. Consider too how many of us are with you here; Odysseus comes ere long; how else? Is there not
comfort in the common fate? ’tis something not to suffer alone. See Heracles, Meleager, and many another great one; they, methinks, would not choose return, if one would send them up to serve poor destitute men.

sp.speaker: Achilles
sp.p: Ay, your intent is friendly; but I know not, the thought of the past life irks me—and each of you too, ifI mistake not. And if you confess it not, the worse for you, smothering your pain;

sp.speaker: Antilochus
sp.p: Not the worse, Achilles; the better; for we see that speech is unavailing. Be silent, bear, endure—that is our resolve, lest such longings bring mockery on us, as on you.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Surely this is Heracles I see? By his godhead, ’tis no other! The bow, the club, the lion’s-skin, the giant frame; 'tis Heracles complete. Yet how should this be?—a son of Zeus and mortal? I say, Mighty Conqueror, are you dead? I used to sacrifice to you in the other world; I understood you were a God!

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Thou didst well. Heracles is with the Gods in Heaven, And hath white-ankled Hebe there to wife. I am his phantom.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: His phantom! What then, can one half of any one be a God, and the other half mortal?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Even so. The God still lives. 'Tis I, his counterpart, am dead.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I see. You’re a dummy; he palms you off upon Pluto, instead of coming himself. And here are you, enjoying his mortality!

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat as thou hast said.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
Well, but where were Aeacus’s keen eyes, that he let
a counterfeit Heracles pass under his very nose, and never knew the difference?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: I was made very like to him.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I believe you! Very like indeed, no difference at all! Why, we may find it’s the other way round, that you are Heracles, and the phantom is in Heaven, married to Hebe!

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Prating knave, no more of thy gibes; else thou shalt presently learn how great a God calls me phantom.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: H’m. That bow looks as if it meant business, And yet,—what have I to fear now? A man can die but once. Tell me, phantom,—by your great Substance I adjure you— did you serve him in your present capacity in the upper world? Perhaps you were one individual during your lives, the separation taking place only at your deaths, when he, the God, soared heavenwards, and you, the phantom, very properly made your appearance here?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Thy ribald questions were best unanswered. Yet thus much thou shalt know.—All that was Amphitryon in Heracles, is dead; I am that mortal part. The Zeus in him lives, and is with the Gods in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Ah, now I see! Alcmena had twins, you mean,— Heracles the son of Zeus, and Heracles the son of Amphitryon? You were really half-brothers all the time?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Fool! not so. We twain were one Heracles.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: It’s a little difficult to grasp, the two Heracleses packed into one. I suppose you must have been like a sort of Centaur, man and God all mixed together?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: And are not all thus composed of two elements,—the body and the soul? What then should hinder the soul from being in Heaven, with Zeus who gave it, and the mortal part— myself—among the dead?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
Yes, yes, my esteemed son of Amphitryon,—that would be all very well if you were a body; but you see you are a
phantom, you have no body. At this rate we shall get three Heracleses.

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Three?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Yes; look here. One in Heaven: one in Hades, that’s you, the phantom: and lastly the body, which by this time has returned to dust. That makes three, Can you think of a good father for number Three?

sp.speaker: Heracles
sp.p: Impudent quibbler! And who art thou?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I am Diogenes’s phantom, late of Sinope. But my original, I assure you, is not ‘among th’ immortal Gods,’ but here among dead men; where he enjoys the best of company, and snaps my fingers at Homer and all hair-splitting.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: What are you crying out about, Tantalus? standing at the edge and whining like that!

sp.speaker: Tantalus
sp.p: Ah, Menippus, I thirst, I perish!

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: What, not enterprise enough to bend down to it, or scoop up some in your palm?

sp.speaker: Tantalus
sp.p: It is no use bending down; the water shrinks away as soon as it sees me coming. And if I do scoop it up and get it to my mouth, the outside of my lips is hardly moist before it has managed to run through my fingers, and my hand is as dry as ever.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: A very odd experience, that. But by the way, why do you want to drink? you have no body—the part of you that was liable to hunger and thirst is buried in Lydia somewhere; how can you, the spirit, hunger or thirst any more?

sp.speaker: Tantalus
sp.p: Therein lies my punishment—soul thirsts as if it were body.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Well, let that pass, as you say thirst is your punishment. But why do you mind it? are you afraid of dying, for want of drink? I do not know of any second Hades; can you die to this one, and go further?

sp.speaker: Tantalus
sp.p: No, that is quite true. But you see this is part of the sentence: I must long for drink, though I have no need of it.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: There is no meaning in that. There is a draught you need, though; some neat hellebore is what you want; you are suffering from a converse hydrophobia; you are not afraid of water, but you are of thirst.

sp.speaker: Tantalus
sp.p: I would as lief drink hellebore as anything, if I could but drink.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Never fear, ‘Tantalus; neither you nor any other ghost will ever do that; it is impossible, you see; just as well we have not all got a penal thirst like you, with the water running away from us.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Where are all the beauties, Hermes? Show me round; I am a new-comer.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: I am busy, Menippus. But look over there to your right, and you will see Hyacinth, Narcissus, Nireus, Achilles, Tyro, Helen, Leda,—all the beauties of old.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I can only see bones, and bare skulls; most of them are exactly alike.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Those bones, of which you seem to think so lightly, have been the theme of admiring poets.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Well, but show me Helen; I shall never be able to make her out by myself.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: This skull is Helen.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p:
And for this a thousand ships carried warriors from every
part of Greece; Greeks and barbarians were slain, and cities made desolate.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p:
Ah, Menippus, you never saw the living Helen; or you would have said with Homer,
Well might they suffer grievous years of toil
Who strove for such a prize. We look at withered flowers, whose dye is gone from them, and what can we call them but unlovely things? Yet in the hour of their bloom these unlovely things were things of beauty.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Strange, that the Greeks could not realize what it was for which they laboured; how short-lived, how soon to fade.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: I have no time for moralizing. Choose your spot, where you will, and lie down. I must go to fetch new dead.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: Now then, Protesilaus, what do you mean by assaulting and throttling Helen?

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Why, it was all her fault that I died, leaving my house half built, and my bride a widow.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: You should blame Menelaus, for taking you all to Troy after such a light-o’-love.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: That is true; he shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Menelaus
sp.p: No, no, my dear sir; Paris surely is the man; he outraged all rights in carrying off his host’s wife with him. He deserves throttling, if you like, and not from you only, but from Greeks and barbarians as well, for all the deaths he brought upon them,

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Ah, now I have it. Here, you—you Paris! you shall not escape my clutches,

sp.speaker: Paris
sp.p:
Oh, come, sir, you will never wrong one of the same gentle craft as yourself. Am I not a lover too, and a subject
of your deity? against love you know (with the best will in the world) how vain it is to strive; ’tis a spirit that draws us whither it will.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: There is reason in that. Oh, would that I had Love himself here in these hands!

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: Permit me to charge myself with his defence. He does not absolutely deny his responsibility for Paris’s love; but that for your death he refers to yourself, Protesilaus. You forgot all about your bride, fell in love with fame, and, directly the fleet touched the Troad, took that rash senseless leap, which brought you first to shore and to death.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Now it is my turn to correct, Aeacus. The blame does not rest with me, but with Fate; so was my thread spun from the beginning.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: Exactly so; then why blame our good friends here?

div.head: Menippus. Aeacus. Empedocles. Socrates. Various Shades

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: In Pluto’s name, Aeacus, show me all the sights of Hades,

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: That would be rather an undertaking, Menippus. However, you shall see the principal things. Cerberus here you know already, and the ferryman who brought you over. And you saw the Styx on your way, and Pyriphlegethon.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Yes, and you are the gate-keeper; I know all that; and I have seen the King and the Furies. But show me the men of ancient days, especially the celebrities.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: This is Agamemnon; this is Achilles; near him, Idomeneus; next comes Odysseus; then Ajax, Diomede, and all the great Greeks.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p:
Why, Homer, Homer, what is this? All your great
heroes flung down upon the earth, shapeless, undistinguishable; mere meaningless dust; ‘strengthless heads,’ and no mistake.—Who is this one, Aeacus?

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: That is Cyrus; and here is Croesus; beyond him Sardanapalus, and beyond him again Midas, And yonder is Xerxes.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Ha! and it was before this creature that Greece trembled? this is our yoker of Hellesponts, our designer of Athoscanals?—Croesus too! a sad spectacle! As to Sardanapalus, I will lend him a box on the ear, with your permission.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: And crack his skull, poor dear! Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Then I must content myself with spitting in his ladyship’s face.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: Would you like to see the philosophers?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I should like it of all things.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: First comes Pythagoras.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Good-day, Euphorbus, alias Apollo, alias what you will.

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Good-day, Menippus.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: What, no golden thigh nowadays?

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Why, no. I wonder if there is anything to eat in that wallet of yours?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Beans, friend; you don’t like beans,

sp.speaker: Pythagoras
sp.p: Try me. My principles have changed with my quarters. I find that down here our parents’ heads are in no way connected with beans.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: Here is Solon, the son of Execestides, and there is Thales, By them are Pittacus, and the rest of the sages, seven in all, as you see,

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: The only resigned and cheerful countenances yet. Who is the one covered with ashes, like a loaf baked in the embers? He is all over blisters,

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: That is Empedocles, He was half-roasted when he got here from Etna.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Tell me, my brazen-slippered friend, what induced you to jump into the crater?

sp.speaker: Empedocles
sp.p: I did it in a fit of melancholy.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Not you. Vanity, pride, folly; these were what burnt you up, slippers and all; and serve you right. All that ingenuity was thrown away, too: your death was detected.—

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: where is Socrates?

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: He is generally talking nonsense with Nestor and Palamedes.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: But I should like to see him, if he is anywhere about.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: You see the bald one?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: They are all bald; that is a distinction without a difference,

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: The snub-nosed one.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: There again: they are all snub-nosed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you want me, Menippus?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: The very man I am looking for.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How goes it in Athens?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: There are a great many young men there professing philosophy; and to judge from their dress and their walk, they should be perfect in it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I have seen many such.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: For that matter, I suppose you saw Aristippus arrive, reeking with scent; and Plato, the polished flatterer from Sicilian courts?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what do they think about me in Athens?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Ah, you are fortunate in that respect. You pass for a most remarkable man, omniscient in fact. And all the time— if the truth must out—you know absolutely nothing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I told them that myself: but they would have it that that was my irony.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: And who are your friends?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Charmides; Phaedrus; the son of Clinias.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Ha, ha! still at your old trade; still an admirer of beauty.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How could I be better occupied? Will you join us?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: No, thank you; I am off, to take up my quarters by Croesus and Sardanapalus. I expect huge entertainment from their outcries.

sp.speaker: Aeacus
sp.p: I must be off, too; or some one may escape. You shall see the rest another day, Menippus.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I need not detain you. I have seen enough.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: My dear coz—for Cerberus and Cynic are surely related through the dog—I adjure you by the Styx, tell me how Socrates behaved during the descent. A God like you can doubtless articulate instead of barking, if he chooses.

sp.speaker: Cerberus
sp.p: Well, while he was some way off, he seemed quite unshaken; and I thought he was bent on letting the people outside realize the fact too. Then he passed into the opening and saw the gloom; I at the same time gave him a touch of the hemlock, and a pull by the leg, as he was rather slow. Then he squalled like a baby, whimpered about his children, and, oh, I don’t know what he didn’t do.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: So he was one of the theorists, was he? his indifference was a sham?

sp.speaker: Cerberus
sp.p: Yes; it was only that he accepted the inevitable, and put a bold face on it, pretending to welcome the universal fate, by way of impressing the bystanders. All that sort are the same, I tell you—bold resolute fellows as far as the entrance; it is inside that the real test comes.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: What did you think of my performance?

sp.speaker: Cerberus
sp.p: Ah, Menippus, you were the exception; you are a credit to the breed, and so was Diogenes before you. You two came in without any compulsion or pushing, of your own free will, with a laugh for yourselves and a curse for the rest.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Your fare, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Bawl away, Charon, if it gives you any pleasure.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: I brought you across: give me my fare.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I can’t, if I haven’t got it.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: And who is so poor that he has not got a penny?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I for one; I don’t know who else.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Pay: or, by Pluto, I'll strangle you.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: And Pll crack your skull with this stick.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: So you are to come all that way for nothing?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Let Hermes pay for me: he put me on board.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: I dare say! A fine time I shall have of it, if I am to pay for the shades.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: I’m not going to let you off.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: You can haul up your ship and wait, for all I care. If I have not got the money, I can’t pay you, can I?

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: You knew you ought to bring it?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I knew that: but I hadn’t got it. What would you have? I ought not to have died, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: So you are to have the distinction of being the only passenger that ever crossed gratis?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Oh, come now: gratis! I took an oar, and I baled; and I didn’t cry, which is more than can be said for any of the others.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: That’s neither here nor there. I must have my penny; it’s only right.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Well, you had better take me back again to life.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Yes, and get a thrashing from Aeacus for my pains! I like that.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Well, don’t bother me.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Let me see what you have got in that wallet.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Beans: have some?—and a Hecate’s supper.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Where did you pick up this Cynic, Hermes? The noise he made on the crossing, too! laughing and jeering at all the rest, and singing, when every one else was at his lamentations.

sp.speaker: Hermes
sp.p: Ah, Charon, you little know your passenger! Independence, every inch of him: he cares for noone. 'Tis Menippus.

sp.speaker: Charon
sp.p: Wait till I catch you——

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Precisely; I'll wait—till you catch me again.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Lord, King, our Zeus! and thou, daughter of Demeter! grant a lover’s boon!

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: What do you want? who are you?

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Protesilaus, son of Iphiclus, of Phylace, one of the Achaean host, the first that died at Troy. And the boon I ask is release and one day’s life.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Ah, friend, that is the love that all these dead men love, and none shall ever win.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Nay, dread lord, ’tis not life I love, but the bride that I left new wedded in my chamber that day I sailed away—ah me, to be slain by Hector as my foot touched land! My lord, that yearning gives me no peace. I return content, if she might look on me but for an hour.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Did you miss your dose of Lethe, man?

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Nay, lord; but this prevailed against it.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Oh, well, wait a little; she will come to you dne day; it is so simple; no need for you to be going up.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: My heart is sick with hope deferred; thou too, O Pluto, hast loved; thou knowest what love is.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: What good will it do you to come to life for a day, and then renew your pains?

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: I think to win her to come with me, and bring two dead for one.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: It may not be; it never has been.

sp.speaker: Protesilaus
sp.p: Bethink thee, Pluto. 'Twas for this same cause that ye gave Orpheus his Eurydice; and Heracles had interest enough to be granted Alcestis; she was of my kin.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Would you like to present that bare ugly skull to your fair bride? will she admit you, when she cannot tell you from another man? I know well enough; she will be frightened and run from you, and you will have gone all that way for nothing.

sp.speaker: Persephone
sp.p: Husband, doctor that disease yourself: tell Hermes, as soon as Protesilaus reaches the light, to touch him with his wand, and make him young and fair as when he left the bridal chamber.

sp.speaker: Pluto
sp.p: Well, I cannot refuse a lady. Hermes, take him up and turn him into a bridegroom. But mind, you sir, a strictly temporary one,

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Why so proud, Carian? How are you better than the rest of us?

sp.speaker: Mausolus
sp.p:
Sinopean, to begin with, I was a king; king of all Caria, ruler of many Lydians, subduer of islands, conqueror of well-nigh the whole of Ionia, even to the borders of Miletus.
Further, I was comely, and of noble stature, and a mighty warrior. Finally, a vast tomb lies over me in Halicarnassus, of such dimensions, of such exquisite beauty as no other shade can boast. Thereon are the perfect semblances of man and horse, carved in the fairest marble; scarcely may a temple be found to match it. These are the grounds of my pride: are they inadequate?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Kingship—beauty—heavy tomb; is that it?

sp.speaker: Mausolus
sp.p: It is as you say.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: But, my handsome Mausolus, the power and the beauty are no longer there. If we were to appoint an umpire now on the question of comeliness, I see no reason why he should prefer your skull to mine. Both are bald, and bare of flesh; our teeth are equally in evidence; each of us has lost his eyes, and each is snub-nosed. Then as to the tomb and the costly marbles, I dare say such a fine erection gives the Halicarnassians something to brag about and show off to strangers: but I don’t see, friend, that you are the better for it, unless it is that you claim to carry more weight than the rest of us, with all that marble on the top of you.

sp.speaker: Mausolus
sp.p: Then all is to go for nothing? Mausolus and Diogenes are to rank as equals?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Equals! My dear sir, no; I don’t say that. While Mausolus is groaning over the memories of earth, and the felicity which he supposed to be his, Diogenes will be chuckling. While Mausolus boasts of the tomb raised to him by Artemisia, his wife and sister, Diogenes knows not whether he has a tomb or no—the question never having occurred to him; he knows only that his name is on the tongues of the wise, as one who lived the life of a man; a higher monument than yours, vile Carian slave, and set on firmer foundations,

sp.speaker: Nireus
sp.p: Here we are; Menippus shall award the palm of beauty, Menippus, am I not better-looking than he?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Well, who are you? I must know that first, mustn’t I?

sp.speaker: Nireus
sp.p: Nireus and Thersites.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Which is which? I cannot tell that yet.

sp.speaker: Thersites
sp.p: One to me; I am like you; you have no such superiority as Homer (blind, by the way) gave you when he called you the handsomest of men; he might peak my head and thin my hair, our judge finds me none the worse. Now, Menippus, make up your mind which is handsomer.

sp.speaker: Nireus
sp.p:
I, of course, I, the son of Aglaia and Charopus,
Comeliest of all that came ’neath Trojan walls.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: But not comeliest of all that come ’neath the earth, as far as I know. Your bones are much like other people’s; and the only difference between your two skulls is that yours would not take much to stove it in. It is a tender article, something short of masculine,

sp.speaker: Nireus
sp.p: Ask Homer what I was, when I sailed with the Achaeans.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Dreams, dreams, I am looking at what you are; what you were is ancient history.

sp.speaker: Nireus
sp.p: Am I not handsomer here, Menippus?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: You are not handsome at all, nor any one else either. Hades is a democracy; one man is as good as another here.

sp.speaker: Thersites
sp.p: And a very tolerable arrangement too, if you ask me.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: I have heard that you were a god, Chiron, and that you died of your own choice?

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: You were rightly informed. I am dead, as you see, and might have been immortal.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: And what should possess you, to be in love with Death? He has no charm for most people.

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: You are a sensible fellow; I will tell you. There was no further satisfaction to be had from immortality.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Was it not a pleasure merely to live and see the light?

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: No; it is variety, as I take it, and not monotony, that constitutes pleasure. Living on and on, everything always the same; sun, light, food, spring, summer, autumn, winter, one thing following another in unending sequence,—I sickened of it all. I found that enjoyment lay not in continual possession; that deprivation had its share therein.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Very true, Chiron. And how have you got on since you made Hades your home?

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: Not unpleasantly. I like the truly republican equality that prevails; and as to whether one is in light or darkness, that makes no difference at all, Then again there is no hunger or thirst here; one is independent of such things.

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Take care, Chiron! You may be caught in the snare of your own reasonings.

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: How should that be?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Why, if the monotony of the other world brought on satiety, the monotony here may do the same. You will have to look about for a further change, and I fancy there is no third life procurable.

sp.speaker: Chiron
sp.p: Then what is to be done, Menippus?

sp.speaker: Menippus
sp.p: Take things as you find them, I suppose, like a sensible fellow, and make the best of everything.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Now, friends, we have plenty of time; what say you to a stroll? we might go to the entrance and have a look at the new-comers—what they are and how they behave.

sp.speaker: Antisthenes
sp.p: The very thing. It will be an amusing sight—some weeping, some imploring to be let go, some resisting; when Hermes collars them, they will stick their heels in and throw their weight back; and all to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Very well; and meanwhile, let me give you my experiences on the way down.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: Yes, go on, Crates; I dare say you saw some entertaining sights.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: We were a large party, of which the most distinguished were Ismenodorus, a rich townsman of ours, Arsaces, ruler of Media, and Oroetes the Armenian. Ismenodorus had been murdered by robbers going to Eleusis over Cithaeron, I believe. He was moaning, nursing his wound, apostrophizing the young children he had left, and cursing his foolhardiness. He knew Cithaeron and the Eleutherae district were all devastated by the wars, and yet he must take only two servants with him— with five bowls and four cups of solid gold in his baggage, too.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p:
Arsaces was an old man of rather imposing aspect; he expressed his feelings in true barbaric fashion, was exceedingly angry at being expected to walk, and kept calling for his horse. In point of factit had died with him, it and he having been simultaneously transfixed by a Thracian pikeman in the fight with the Cappadocians on the Araxes, Arsaces described to us how he had
charged far in advance of his men, and the Thracian, standing his ground and sheltering himself with his buckler, warded off the lance, and then, planting his pike, transfixed man and horse together.

sp.speaker: Antisthenes
sp.p: How could it possibly be done simultaneously?

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: Oh, quite simple, The Median was charging with his thirty-foot lance in front of him; the Thracian knocked it aside with his buckler; the point glanced by; then he knelt, received the charge on his pike, pierced the horse’s chest—the spirited beast impaling itself by its own impetus—, and finally ran Arsaces through groin and buttock. You see what happened; it was the horse’s doing rather than the man’s. However, Arsaces did not at all appreciate equality, and wanted to come down on horseback.

sp.speaker: Crato
sp.p: As for Oroetes, he was so tender-footed that he could not stand, far less walk. That is the way with all the Medes—once they are off their horses, they go delicately on tiptoe as if they were treading on thorns. He threw himself down, and there he lay; nothing would induce him to get up; so the excellent Hermes had to pick him up and carry him to the ferry; how I laughed!

sp.speaker: Antisthenes
sp.p: When I came down, I did not keep with the crowd; I left them to their blubberings, ran on to the ferry, and secured a comfortable seat for the passage. Then as we crossed, they were divided between tears and sea-sickness, and gave me a merry time of it.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p:
You two have described your fellow passengers; now for mine. There came down with me Blepsias, the Pisatan usurer, Lampis, an Acarnanian freelance, and the Corinthian millionaire Damis, The last had been poisoned by his son, Lampis had cut his throat for love of the courtesan Myrtium, and the wretched Blepsias is supposed to have died of starvation; his awful pallor and extreme emaciation looked like it. I inquired into the manner of their deaths, though I knew very
well. When Damis exclaimed upon his son, ‘You only have your deserts,’ I remarked,—‘an old man of ninety living in luxury yourself with your million of money, and fobbing off your eighteen-year son with a few pence! As for you, sir Acarnanian’—he was groaning and cursing Myrtium—, ‘why put the blame on Love? it belongs to yourself; you were never afraid of an enemy—took all sorts of risks in other people’s service—and then let yourself be caught, my hero, by the artificial tears and sighs of the first wench you came across.’ Blepsias uttered his own condemnation, without giving me time to do it for him: he had hoarded his money for heirs who were nothing to him, and been fool enough to reckon on immortality. I assure you it was no common satisfaction I derived from their whinings.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: But here we are at the gate; we must keep our eyes open, and get the earliest view. Lord, lord, what a mixed crowd! and all in tears except these babes and sucklings. Why, the hoary seniors are all lamentation too; strange! has madam Life given them a love-potion?

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I must interrogate this most reverend senior of them all.—Sir, why weep, seeing that you have died full of years? has your excellency any complaint to make, after so long a term? Ah, but you were doubtless a king.

sp.speaker: Pauper
sp.p: Not so.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: A provincial governor, then?

sp.speaker: Pauper
sp.p: No, nor that.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: I see; you were wealthy, and do not like leaving your boundless luxury to die.

sp.speaker: Pauper
sp.p: You are quite mistaken; I was near ninety, made a miserable livelihood out of my line and rod, was excessively poor, childless, a cripple, and had nearly lost my sight.

sp.speaker: Diogenes
sp.p: And you still wished to live?

sp.speaker: Pauper
sp.p: Ay, sweet is the light, and dread is death; would that one might escape it!

sp.speaker: Diogenes
